docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Toledo Wins Peru Election That Disenchanted Voters Alejandro Toledo, left, won the presidency over onetime President Alan García after a campaign that left Peruvians deeply disillusioned. Mr. Toledo succeeds Alberto K. Fujimori, who oversaw a decade of corrupt and authoritarian rule before fleeing into exile in November. With almost 75 percent of the vote counted, Mr. Toledo had won 51.83 percent to Mr. García's 48.17. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A May 29 front-page article says ''information on incompetent doctors is included in a computer system known as the National Practitioner Data Bank.'' That the ''incompetent'' label is quickly attached to the doctors reported in the database shows why caution must be exercised before making it public, as some advocate.
docs.abstract: Dr Wendell Ocasio letter on May 29 article holds many competent doctors settle malpractice suits and would be unfairly labeled incompetent should National Practioner Data Bank be made public; drawing

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''U.S. and Albany Agree to Provide Health Benefits to Uninsured Poor'' (front page, May 30): The Pataki administration has finally given Washington the data needed to win federal approval of Family Health Plus, to provide free health coverage for several hundred thousand low-income working adults.
docs.abstract: Assemblyman Richard N Gottfried letter on May 30 article urges Gov George E Pataki to back bill to cut red tape that keeps over one million uninsured New Yorkers from getting health coverage they are eligible for under Medicaid and Child Health Plus

docs.lead_paragraph: Cindy Shipper rested comfortably with her newborn son, Tzvi, while his twin sister, Sarah, napped in a nearby nursery. Soon Mrs. Shipper would enjoy a fine meal, then fall off to sleep in her tastefully decorated room, complete with freshly cut flowers. As well behaved as her three other children -- ages 7, 5 and 3 -- are, there is little likelihood that Mrs. Shipper, who had given birth to the twins just days ago, would have this kind of a chance to recuperate from childbirth at her home in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.
docs.abstract: Article describes luxury amenities and care provided to new mothers and newborn babies from Hasidic Jewish community, discharged quickly by hospitals, at 36-bed post-partum center at Leisure Chateau nursing home in Lakewood, NJ; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Like the rest of the country's hospitals, Mpilo Central is sick. Mpilo, the biggest hospital here in Zimbabwe's second-biggest city, is losing its doctors, its nurses, its pharmacists and, slowly, its spirit.

headline.main: Zimbabwe Doctors Flee As AIDS Crisis Widens

docs.abstract: Medical professionals are abandoning Zimbabwe as never before, fleeing deepening hardships there and following lure of opportunities elsewhere; business executives, teachers, engineers and others are also leaving, costing Zimbabwe much of enormously successful investment it made in education after blacks won majority rule 21 years ago; Zimbabwe's economy, once one of Africa's most promising, is a wreck; standoff over how white-owned farmland should be redistributed has roiled country and harmed agriculture, its economic base; exports and tourism are also down; World Bank and International Monetary Fund have cut Zimbabwe off, and Pres Robert Mugabe refuses to make concessions in state's policies and priorities to get them back; photos; map (M)
docs.snippet: Like the rest of the country's hospitals, Mpilo Central is sick.    Mpilo, the biggest hospital here in Zimbabwe's second-biggest city, is losing its doctors, its nurses, its pharmacists and, slowly, its spirit.

docs.lead_paragraph: Elsie Carter's morning routine never varies. She awakens at 6:30 to feed the cats, George and Sam, named for her friends, fellow AIDS patients who died. Then she butters a slice of toast and pours a tall tumbler of orange juice -- ''to put a little something in my stomach,'' Ms. Carter explains -- as she ingests the veritable pharmacy that keeps her alive. One by one, she picks her pills out of a crowded plastic box. They look pretty, like an assortment of colored gems. Ms. Carter, a recovering heroin addict who was so sick three years ago that she entered a hospice, says the medicines make her feel like ''I'm toxic.''

headline.main: In AIDS War, New Weapons and New Victims

docs.abstract: First article in series, AIDS at 20, examines changing face of epidemic; finds that AIDS in America can be survivable, thanks to so-called drug cocktails of antiviral medicines which have brought countless people back from brink of death; AIDS has killed more than 438,000 Americans and nearly 22 million people worldwide since 1981; it is no longer confined to gay men and intravenous drug abusers; in America, it is increasingly epidemic of the poor, which means increasingly minorities; blacks, who make up 13 percent of population, account for more than half of all new HIV infections; AIDS is leading case of death among blacks aged 25 to 44; disease still carries social stigma so strong that sometimes biggest burden of having HIV is keeping it secret; photos; charts; graph (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Graduate teaching assistants at the University of Washington went on strike, demanding improved health insurance and restrictions on their teaching load. The strike was called by the Graduate Student Employee Action Coalition, a branch of the United Auto Workers that represents more than 1,000 graduate teaching and research assistants. The union wants to be recognized as their bargaining agent, but university officials insist that, without state legislation, they are not authorized to grant such recognition. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Teaching Assistants Strike

docs.abstract: Graduate teaching assistants at University of Washington strike for improved health insurance and decreased teaching loads (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast. Opera ''FALSTAFF.'' The diminutive Amato Opera company, a fixture on the New York opera scene, is presenting the last production of its 53rd season, Verdi's ''Falstaff,'' on weekends through June 17. Verdi's last masterpiece is getting a lot of stage time this season as the music world commemorates the 100th anniversary of his death. This production, however, is a revival, with sets and costumes by Richard Cerullo, the company's designer for two decades, and conducted by Tony Amato, the pop of this venerable mom-and-pop operation. Saturday night at 7:30, Sunday at 2:30 p.m., Amato Opera Theater, 319 Bowery, at Second Street, East Village, (212) 228-8200. Tickets: $25, seniors and children under 12, $20 (Anne Midgette).

docs.lead_paragraph: The New York City Department of Health will pay a lump sum to allow 15 school health clinics scheduled for closing to remain open until next year, officials with the operator of the clinics said yesterday. The New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, the operator of the clinics, had sought the state's permission to shut down 27 school-based and neighborhood clinics that serve poor children because the clinics were bleeding cash.

headline.main: 15 School Health Clinics Scheduled for Closing Get a Reprieve

docs.abstract: New York City Dept of Health will pay $530,000 to allow 15 school health clinics scheduled for closing to remain open until next year, giving Health and Hospitals Corp time to seek additional state funding (M)
docs.snippet: The New York City Department of Health will pay a lump sum to allow 15 school health clinics scheduled for closing to remain open until next year, officials with the operator of the clinics said yesterday.    The New York City Health and Hospitals...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Health and Hospitals Corporation, a public agency that is the medical care provider of last resort in New York City, is now withdrawing its request to the state to close 15 clinics in schools in low-income neighborhoods. The agency had made the controversial proposal to cut its costs, but city officials have since discovered that New York's health department is obligated to provide a nurse for each school if the clinics close, reducing the cost savings from shutting the clinics. Instead the city has decided to pick up some of the health agency's costs to keep the clinics open. The survival of these clinics, which provide free examinations and medicine to children with such problems as asthma, ear infections and stomach ailments, will ensure that many poor children get needed health care. But the agency still faces a crisis in maintaining its outpatient clinics, and must deal with a deficit of nearly $300 million this year. To cut a few million dollars from its budget, it is asking the state for permission to close 12 other outpatient clinics in underserved, largely immigrant communities. Most of the clinics have already been temporarily shuttered, and in some cases patients can be shifted with few problems. But state officials should keep clinics open when there is no acceptable alternative, and then, along with city officials, commit themselves to providing the agency with enough money to allow it to fulfill its mission of treating New Yorkers regardless of ability to pay.
docs.abstract: Editorial says Health and Hospitals Corp, medical care provider of last resort in New York City, has reversed its controversial proposal to close 15 clinics in schools in low-income neighborhoods, but it now seeks to close 12 other outpatient clinics in underserved, largely immigrant communities; says New York City used to subsidize agency's deficit, which this year is $300 million, but Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has gradually reduced these payments; says city must assure adequate financing of clinics, or it will be abandoning its historic commitment to public health
